Knowledge Point: The \textsc{determiner} slot can be filled with demonstratives (\ref{ex512}), interrogatives (\ref{ex513}), \isi{possessive} pronouns (\ref{ex514}) and whole \isi{noun phrase}s inflected for one of the adnominal cases. These include the \isi{possessive} (\ref{ex515}), \isi{temporal} \isi{possessive} (\ref{ex516}) and \isi{characteristic} \isi{case} (\ref{ex517}). In the following examples, \isi{noun phrase}s are marked by square brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc {fi keke zä wrugr [\textbf{zane} gwthen}]. | \gll fi keke zä w\stem{rugr} zane gwth=en. | \gls Third.ABS NEG PROX TSG.F:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/sleep DEM:PROX nest=LOC. | \glt `She does not sleep in this nest here.'
Content 3: \gsrc {[\textbf{nzone} trikasi}] fobo fof zwaythk. | \gll nzone trik-si fobo fof zwa\stem{ythk}. | \gls FSG.POSS tell-NMLZ DIST.All EMPH TSG.F:SBJ:Rpst:IPFV/come.to.end. | \glt `My story has come to an end there.'
Content 4: \gsrc wth fobo fof thämira ... [[\textbf{ane kabeane}}] wth]. | \gll wth fobo fof thä\stem{mir}a ... ane kabe=ane wth. | \gls intestines DIST.All EMPH STSG:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:PFV/hang ... DEM man=POSS intestines. | \glt `She hung the intestines there ... that man's intestines.'
Content 5: \gsrc {[[\textbf{kaythamane}}] karo] rä!} | \gll kayé=thamane karo \stem{rä}. | \gls yesterday=TEMP.POSS ground.oven TSG.F:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be. | \glt `It is yesterday's oven.'
Content 6: \gsrc {[[\textbf{baguma}}] kabe] ... foba ... zena mifnen zämnzr. | \gll bagu=ma kabe ... foba ... zena mifne=n z=ä\stem{m}nzr. | \gls bagu=CHAR man ... DIST.ABL ... now mifne=LOC PROX=STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/dwell. | \glt `The Bagu people ... from over there ... live here in Mifne (or: Mibini) today.'

Knowledge Point: These different fillers cannot co-occur. Consider example (\ref{ex518}), which is taken from a nzürna trikasi, a local equivalent to European witch stories. The example contains the complex \isi{noun phrase} nä karma kabe, in which the \isi{indefinite} nä `some, another' and kar=ma `from the village' are both candidates for the \textsc{determiner} slot. However, the \isi{indefinite} does not refer to kabe `man', but to kar `village'. In other words, the \isi{indefinite} fills the \textsc{determiner} slot of the embedded \isi{noun phrase}, and the embedded \isi{noun phrase} fills the \textsc{determiner} slot of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}. This is shown with square brackets in the example. Note that (\ref{ex515}) shows the same structure.
Content 1: \gsrc {[[\textbf{nä karma}] \textbf{kabe}}] mane yanatha ... mogarkamma} | \gll nä kar=ma kabe mane ya\stem{na}tha ... mogarkam=ma. | \gls INDF village=CHAR man which STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:PST:IPFV/eat ... mogarkam=CHAR. | \glt `It was a man from another village who she ate ... from Mogarkam.'
Content 2: \gsrc wth fobo fof thämira ... [[\textbf{ane kabeane}}] wth]. | \gll wth fobo fof thä\stem{mir}a ... ane kabe=ane wth. | \gls intestines DIST.All EMPH STSG:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:PFV/hang ... DEM man=POSS intestines. | \glt `She hung the intestines there ... that man's intestines.'

Knowledge Point: The \isi{determiner} can appear in postposed position, which I analyse as non-prototypical order. The rest of this section describes this postposed position of the \isi{determiner}. Example (\ref{ex524}) is taken from the same story as the previous example. The \isi{noun phrase} tüfr yam nä `many other things' contains the \isi{quantifier} tüfr in the \textsc{premodifier} slot, the noun yam `event' in the \textsc{head} slot, and the \isi{indefinite} nä in postposed position. This \isi{noun phrase} can be arranged in different orders, for example: nä tüfr yam, nä yam tüfr. However, the \textsc{determiner} and \textsc{premodifier} slots cannot be exchanged. This order of elements, for example tüfr nä yam, would be split into two co-referential \isi{noun phrase}s, which is signalled by a break in the intonation contour and case marking on both \isi{noun phrase}s. Case markers would attach to tüfr as well as nä yam.
Content 1: \gsrc {[\textbf{tüfr yam nä}}] fefe thwafiyokwrm ... fi fathfa ane fof wäfiyokwa. | \gll tüfr yam nä fefe thwa\stem{fiyok}wrm ... fi fath=fa ane fof wä\stem{fiyok}wa. | \gls plenty event INDF really SG:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:DUR/make ... but clear.place=ABL DEM EMPH SG:SBJ>TSG.F:OBJ:PST:IPFV/make. | \glt `She really did many other things ... but she did this in public.'

Knowledge Point: We saw in (\ref{ex518}) that the \isi{determiner} belongs to the \isi{head} of the embedded \isi{noun phrase} and not to the \isi{head} of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}. In such cases, the embedded \isi{noun phrase} `blocks' the \textsc{determiner} slot, and postposing a \isi{determiner} is the only option for it to refer to the \isi{head} of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}. This is shown in (\ref{ex519}), where the postposed \isi{indefinite} nä refers to the \isi{head} of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}. The embedded \isi{noun phrase} safsma is marked with the \isi{characteristic} \isi{case} in adnominal function. It specifies the \isi{head} of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}: safsma kabe `man from Safs'. Note that the same could be expressed by a \isi{nominal} compound safs kabe `Safs man'. The semantic difference between an embedded \isi{noun phrase} marked with the \isi{characteristic} \isi{case} and a \isi{nominal} compound lies in the reference of the \isi{determiner}: ane safs kabe `that Safs man' versus ane safsma kabe `man from that Safs' (i.e. not from some other place called Safs). It follows that the two elements in (\ref{ex519}) restrict the reference of the \isi{head} simultaneously: the embedded \isi{noun phrase} safma and the postposed \isi{determiner} nä. A postposed \isi{determiner} usually occurs only if the \isi{noun phrase} is not flagged with a \isi{case} marker. But there are exceptions to this. See (\ref{ex523}) discussed below.
Content 1: \gsrc {[[\textbf{nä karma}] \textbf{kabe}}] mane yanatha ... mogarkamma} | \gll nä kar=ma kabe mane ya\stem{na}tha ... mogarkam=ma. | \gls INDF village=CHAR man which STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:PST:IPFV/eat ... mogarkam=CHAR. | \glt `It was a man from another village who she ate ... from Mogarkam.'
Content 2: \gsrc {[[\textbf{safsma}}] \textbf{woga nä}}] fobo swamnzrm ... gfi yf} | \gll safs=ma woga nä fobo swa\stem{m}nzrm ... gfi yf. | \gls safs=CHAR man INDF DIST.All TSG.MASC:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/dwell ... gfi name. | \glt `Another man from Safs lived there ... by the name of Gfi.'
Content 3: \gsrc {[[\textbf{safsma}}] \textbf{woga nä}}] fobo swamnzrm ... gfi yf} | \gll safs=ma woga nä fobo swa\stem{m}nzrm ... gfi yf. | \gls safs=CHAR man INDF DIST.All TSG.MASC:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/dwell ... gfi name. | \glt `Another man from Safs lived there ... by the name of Gfi.'
Content 4: \gsrc wati [\textbf{gwamf ane}}] fof ezi ŋatha thäsa thgathgen. | \gll wati gwam=f ane fof ezi ŋatha thä\stem{s}a thgathg=en. | \gls then gwam=ERG.SG DEM EMPH morning dog STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:PST:PFV/call burned.place=LOC. | \glt `Well, that Gwam called the dogs to the burned place in the morning.'

Knowledge Point: Although very rare, both \textsc{determiner} slots \textendash{} that of the embedded \isi{noun phrase} and that of the matrix \isi{noun phrase} \textendash{} can be filled. In (\ref{ex553}), the first \isi{non-singular} \isi{possessive} nzenme refers to mayawa, the \isi{head} of the embedded \isi{noun phrase}, and the \isi{indefinite} \isi{determiner} nä refers to kabe, the \isi{head} of the matrix \isi{noun phrase}.
Content 1: \gsrc {[[\textbf{nzenme mayawama}}] \textbf{kabe nä}}] fä thägathizath. | \gll nzenme mayawa=ma kabe nä fä thägathizath. | \gls FNSG.POSS mayawa=CHAR man INDF DIST STPL:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:IPFV/leave. | \glt `They left some of our Mayawa people there.'

Knowledge Point: It follows from the discussion above that two determiners must belong to different \isi{noun phrase}s if they occur next to each other, like zane and nä in example (\ref{ex521}). In this example, I analyse zane as a \isi{noun phrase} with an omitted \isi{head}.
Content 1: \gsrc {[\textbf{zane}}] [\textbf{nä yawi}}] yé. | \gll zane nä yawi \stem{yé}. | \gls DEM:PROX INDF round.object TSG.MASC:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be. | \glt `This is another fruit.'

Knowledge Point: The elements in the \textsc{determiner} slot cannot be inflected for the full range of cases. For example, demonstratives cannot be inflected for \isi{ergative}, dative, \isi{possessive} and the three spatial cases. In (\ref{ex522}), the \isi{indefinite} nä is interpreted as referring to the \isi{object} argument, rather than the \isi{ergative} marked argument.
Content 1: \gsrc {[nof] [\textbf{nä}}] nima thäkothmako. | \gll no=f nä nima thä\stem{kothm}ako. | \gls water=ERG INDF like.this SG:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:PFV:ANDAT/chase. | \glt `The flood chased away others like this.'

Knowledge Point: However, elicitation has shown that even this is possible, but such a structure is very rare. A textual example is shown in (\ref{ex523}), where ane refers to the preceding noun, which is flagged with an \isi{ergative}. Note that in this example, ane is followed by the \isi{emphatic} \isi{particle} fof, which has always scope over the preceding phrase ({\S}\ref{discourse-particles}). Thus, fof may `help' to mark the right edge of the \isi{noun phrase} gwamf ane. This is, however, not the main function of fof.
Content 1: \gsrc wati [\textbf{gwamf ane}}] fof ezi ŋatha thäsa thgathgen. | \gll wati gwam=f ane fof ezi ŋatha thä\stem{s}a thgathg=en. | \gls then gwam=ERG.SG DEM EMPH morning dog STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:PST:PFV/call burned.place=LOC. | \glt `Well, that Gwam called the dogs to the burned place in the morning.'

Knowledge Point: Syntactic evidence for the possibility of postposing the \isi{determiner} comes from fronted relative clauses which are commonly used for topicalisation ({\S}\ref{info-cleft}). Fronted relative clauses of this type have the following structure: NP mane \textsc{copula}. They only allow a full \isi{noun phrase} before the relative \isi{pronoun} mane `which, who'. In (\ref{ex528}), the \isi{noun phrase} includes the postposed \isi{indefinite} \isi{determiner} nä following its \isi{head} ŋatha `dog'. The fronted \isi{relative clause} is marked by square brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc fi ([\textbf{kafar ŋatha nä}}] mane erera) fi ane bä bkwaruthrmth büdisnen mnz znen. | \gll fi kafar ŋatha nä mane e\stem{rä}ra fi ane bä b=kwa\stem{ru}thrmth büdisn=en mnz zn=en. | \gls but big dog INDF which STPL:SBJ:PST:IPFV/be Third.ABS DEM MED MED=STPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/bark Pl=LOC house place=LOC. | \glt `But, as for the other big dogs, they were barking there in Büdisn at the house.'

Knowledge Point: The elements in the \textsc{modifier} slots are different from those in the \textsc{determiner} slot. They can all be inflected for \isi{case} if they happen to occur as the last element of the \isi{noun phrase}. This is shown in (\ref{ex525}) and (\ref{ex526}). In example (\ref{ex525}), the \isi{modifier} is an \isi{adjective} in the \textsc{premodifier} slot. In example (\ref{ex526}), the adjective follows the \isi{head} in the \textsc{postmodifier} slot, and consequently the \isi{adjective} receives the \isi{case} marker.
Content 1: \gsrc finzo fä fof \textbf{ane kafar emothf} thwathofiknm. | \gll fi=nzo fä fof ane kafar emoth=f thwa\stem{thofik}nm. | \gls Third.ABS=ONLY DIST EMPH DEM big girl=ERG.SG SG:SBJ>STDU:OBJ:PST:DUR/disturb. | \glt `Only they (were) there. That big girl was disturbing them.'
Content 2: \gsrc watik \textbf{yfö katanr} kwa yarenzr. | \gll watik yfö katan=r kwa ya\stem{re}nzr. | \gls then hole small=PURP FUT TSG.MASC:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/look. | \glt `Then, he will look around for a small hole.'
Content 3: \gsrc finzo fä fof \textbf{ane kafar emothf} thwathofiknm. | \gll fi=nzo fä fof ane kafar emoth=f thwa\stem{thofik}nm. | \gls Third.ABS=ONLY DIST EMPH DEM big girl=ERG.SG SG:SBJ>STDU:OBJ:PST:DUR/disturb. | \glt `Only they (were) there. That big girl was disturbing them.'
Content 4: \gsrc watik \textbf{yfö katanr} kwa yarenzr. | \gll watik yfö katan=r kwa ya\stem{re}nzr. | \gls then hole small=PURP FUT TSG.MASC:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/look. | \glt `Then, he will look around for a small hole.'

Knowledge Point: There are some restrictions for specific elements, for example the locationals can only inflect for spatial cases. Furthermore, all locationals ({\S}\ref{locationals-sec}) and a few adjectives ({\S}\ref{adjectives-sec}) only occur in the \textsc{postmodifier} slot, not in the \textsc{premodifier} slot. One such adjective is kwark `late, deceased' in (\ref{ex527}). It occurs in the \textsc{postmodifier} slot, and therefore it is flagged with the \isi{ergative} \isi{case}. Note that the proper name Wäni is also inflected with the \isi{ergative} and forms a \isi{noun phrase} co-referential to nafaŋafe kwark `his late father'.
Content 1: \gsrc wati ... \textbf{nafaŋafe kwarkf} ... wänif krekariso} | \gll wati ... nafa-ŋafe kwark=f ... wäni=f kre\stem{karis}o. | \gls then ... Third.POSS-father deceased=ERG.SG ... wäni=ERG.SG SG:SBJ:IRR:PFV:ANDAT/hear. | \glt `Then, his late father, Wäni, heard (about it).'

Knowledge Point: The lack of textual examples which display all possible fillers at once is best explained by a strong tendency to distribute information over several co-referential \isi{noun phrase}s, either in the same clause or over a series of clauses. This can be seen in examples like (\ref{ex527}), (\ref{ex528}) or (\ref{ex529}). I will address this topic in the following section.
Content 1: \gsrc wati ... \textbf{nafaŋafe kwarkf} ... wänif krekariso} | \gll wati ... nafa-ŋafe kwark=f ... wäni=f kre\stem{karis}o. | \gls then ... Third.POSS-father deceased=ERG.SG ... wäni=ERG.SG SG:SBJ:IRR:PFV:ANDAT/hear. | \glt `Then, his late father, Wäni, heard (about it).'
Content 2: \gsrc fi ([\textbf{kafar ŋatha nä}}] mane erera) fi ane bä bkwaruthrmth büdisnen mnz znen. | \gll fi kafar ŋatha nä mane e\stem{rä}ra fi ane bä b=kwa\stem{ru}thrmth büdisn=en mnz zn=en. | \gls but big dog INDF which STPL:SBJ:PST:IPFV/be Third.ABS DEM MED MED=STPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/bark Pl=LOC house place=LOC. | \glt `But, as for the other big dogs, they were barking there in Büdisn at the house.'

Knowledge Point: However, before discussing those two points I want to make a general point about \isi{noun phrase}s in Komnzo. It is quite common to have multiple co-referential \isi{noun phrase}s. These can occur in the same clause or across a sequence of clauses. In example (\ref{ex529}), the speaker talks about an old woman who was married to three men in her lifetime, but she had children only with one of them. Several \isi{noun phrase}s are co-referential. In the example, they are indexed with subscripted numbers.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: At the other end of the spectrum, \isi{noun phrase}s can be wholly omitted, since the indexation in the verb is sufficient. In this way, a single verb often stands as a whole clause. Example (\ref{ex534}) describes the path which the ancestor took and what actions he did along the way. Since the protagonist is highly topical at this point in the story, the respective \isi{noun phrase} is left out. Moreover, the last two verbs zwafrmnzrm `he was preparing it (\F)' and zurzirakwa `he tied it (\F)' occur without any \isi{noun phrase}s. That is because the \isi{object} \isi{noun phrase} (nabi ŋatr `bowstring') was mentioned already.
Content 1: \gsrc nabi ŋatr fä fof zurärm zwafrmnzrm ... zurzirakwa fof. | \gll nabi ŋatr fä fof zu\stem{rä}rm zwa\stem{frm}nzrm ... zu\stem{rzirak}wa fof. | \gls bamboo bowstring DIST EMPH SG:SBJ>TSG.F:OBJ:PST:DUR/do SG:SBJ>TSG.F:OBJ:PST:DUR/prepare ... SG:SBJ>TSG.F:OBJ:PST:IPFV/tie EMPH. | \glt `Over there, he made his bowstring. He prepared it. He tied it.'

Knowledge Point: The \isi{head} of a \isi{noun phrase} is often omitted. Consider example (\ref{ex535}), where a mother tells me that she had sent two small children to dig for worms. The example starts out with the \isi{noun phrase} zane edawä kakatan `these two small (ones)'. Ellipsis of the \isi{head} only occurs when the \isi{head} is recoverable from previous context, or if it is common ground between speaker and hearer.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{zane edawä kakatan} ... fosam daisy fi zarath dd etharinath} | \gll zane eda=wä ka-katan ... fosam daisy fi za\stem{r}ath dd e\stem{thari}nath. | \gls DEM:PROX two=EMPH REDUP-small ... fosam daisy Third.ABS STDU:SBJ:PST:PFV/do worm STDU:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:IPFV/dig. | \glt `These two small (ones), Fosam and Daisy, they did that. They dug the worms.'

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex536}) shows the \isi{indefinite} \isi{demonstrative} nä used twice without a \isi{head}. This is possible because the appropriate filler for the \textsc{head} slot zuzi `fishing line' was already mentioned.
Content 1: \gsrc zuzi thethkäfath migsi ... \textbf{nä} zba wazi ... \textbf{nä} boba wazi. | \gll zuzi the\stem{thkäf}ath mig-si ... nä zba wazi ... nä boba wazi. | \gls fishing.line STPL:SBJ>STPL:OBJ:PST:PFV/start hang-NMLZ ... INDF PROX.ABL side ... INDF MED.ABL side. | \glt `They started hanging the fishing lines ... some on this side and some on the other side.'

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex537}) is a description of a fish trap. These long bamboo baskets always consist of a larger basket and a smaller basket which is placed inside the bigger one. In the example, the speaker refers to the smaller basket as nafane nge `its child' and later only with an adjective katan `small' which is flagged with an \isi{ergative} \isi{case} marker.
Content 1: \gsrc nafane nge ... wati kofä fthé brigsir n krär ... \textbf{katanf} kwa ynbrigwr zbo ... keke kwa kränmätr. | \gll nafane nge ... wati kofä fthé brig-si=r n krä\stem{r} ... katan=f kwa yn\stem{brig}wr zbo ... keke kwa krän\stem{mätr}. | \gls TSG.POSS child ... then fish when return-NMLZ=PURP IMN STSG:SBJ:IRR:PFV/do ... small=ERG FUT STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV:VENIT/return PROX.All ... NEG FUT STSG:SBJ:IRR:PFV:VENIT/exit. | \glt `Its child ... well, when the fish tries to return, the small (one) will bring it back here ... it will not get out.'

Knowledge Point: Compounds can be embedded within one another, which can lead to combinations of usually up to three elements. A rare example of a compound with four elements was coined by one of my informants to describe the botanist on our team: wämne taga yf kabe (lit. `tree leaf name man'). Embedded compounds are always left-branching, and thus we can represent long compounds in this way: [[[wämne taga]\textsubscript{3} yf]\textsubscript{2} kabe]\textsubscript{1}. Two corpus examples of longer compounds are given in (\ref{ex510}) and (\ref{ex511}).
Content 1: \gsrc ane \textbf{ksi kar emoth} thwanorm} | \gll ane ksi kar emoth thwa\stem{nor}m. | \gls DEM bush place girl STPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/shout. | \glt `These bush girls were shouting.'
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{baf} fthé sräbth nima ... \textbf{kabe zan miyof}} | \gll baf fthé srä\stem{bth} nima ... kabe zan miyo=f. | \gls Recog.ERG.SG when STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:IRR:PFV/finish like.this ... man hitting desire=ERG. | \glt `That is when it overcomes him ... that bloodlust for people.'

Knowledge Point: Complex heads are different from complex \isi{noun phrase}s, that is, compounds in the \textsc{head} slot are distinct from embedded \isi{noun phrase}s. The latter must be marked with adnominal \isi{case}. Let us take the compound from example (\ref{ex510}): ane ksi kar emoth `those bush girls' (lit. `bush place girls'). We can embed the \isi{noun phrase} ksi kar `bush place' into the matrix \isi{noun phrase} by adding the \isi{characteristic} \isi{case} (=ma): ksi karma emoth `girls from the bush'. In addition to \isi{case} marking, the reference of the \isi{demonstrative} ane in initial position depends on whether a \isi{noun phrase} is embedded or the \isi{head} contains a compound. In the former \isi{case}, ane refers to the \isi{head} of the embedded \isi{noun phrase}: ane ksi karma emoth `girls from that bush place'. If the \isi{head} slot contains a compound, and no embedding takes place, the \isi{demonstrative} refers to the compound, as in (\ref{ex510}). The reference of the \textsc{determiner} slot is described above in {\S}\ref{npsyntaxdeterminer}.
Content 1: \gsrc ane \textbf{ksi kar emoth} thwanorm} | \gll ane ksi kar emoth thwa\stem{nor}m. | \gls DEM bush place girl STPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/shout. | \glt `These bush girls were shouting.'
Content 2: \gsrc ane \textbf{ksi kar emoth} thwanorm} | \gll ane ksi kar emoth thwa\stem{nor}m. | \gls DEM bush place girl STPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/shout. | \glt `These bush girls were shouting.'

Knowledge Point: Property nouns can appear in both positions of a compound (see \tabref{nomcompounds} above). If a \isi{property noun} occurs as the first element, it modifies the \isi{head} of the compound, for example wri kabe `drunkard' in \tabref{nomcompounds}. Property nouns optionally take the \isi{adjectivaliser} -thé. When this suffix is present, for example in writhé kabe, it is clear that the derived \isi{adjective} appears in the \textsc{modifer-1} slot, and is not part of a compound. The semantic difference is between wri kabe `drunkard' \textendash{} someone who is frequently drunk \textendash{} and writhé kabe `drunk man' \textendash{} someone who is drunk. Syntactically, the derived \isi{adjective} behaves like other adjectives, for example it can appear after the \isi{head} in the \textsc{postmodifier} slot. Without the \isi{adjectivaliser}, a change in order would change the meaning of the compound, e.g. kabe wri `people's / men's intoxication'. However, as mentioned above, the \isi{adjectivaliser} suffix is optional for property nouns. Additionally, property nouns can function predicatively (\ref{ex538}). This creates some problems for the analysis of particular examples.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Lastly, I want to address compounds which involve nominalised verbs. Consider the compounds in (\ref{ex539}) and (\ref{ex540}). In (\ref{ex539}), the speaker points out that these were mgthksi ruga `raised pigs' as opposed to wild pigs. In (\ref{ex540}), the speaker stresses that he has raised enough pigs in his life, and that ruga mgthksi `pig feeding' is too much work.
Content 1: \gsrc ruga tabrunzo erera nima berä ... \textbf{mgthksi ruga}} | \gll ruga tabru=nzo e\stem{rä}ra nima b=e\stem{rä} ... mgthk-si ruga. | \gls pig five=ONLY STPL:SBJ:PST:IPFV/be like.this MED=STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be ... feed-NMLZ pig. | \glt `There were only five pigs like these ... raised pigs.'
Content 2: \gsrc zena keke miyo worä \textbf{ruga mgthksi} ... znsä ttüfr} | \gll zena keke miyo wo\stem{rä} ruga mgthk-si ... znsä t-tüfr. | \gls today NEG desire FSG:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be pig feed-NMLZ ... work REDUP-plenty. | \glt `Today, I do not want to feed pigs ... too much work.' (lit. `I do not desire pig feeding.')
Content 3: \gsrc ruga tabrunzo erera nima berä ... \textbf{mgthksi ruga}} | \gll ruga tabru=nzo e\stem{rä}ra nima b=e\stem{rä} ... mgthk-si ruga. | \gls pig five=ONLY STPL:SBJ:PST:IPFV/be like.this MED=STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be ... feed-NMLZ pig. | \glt `There were only five pigs like these ... raised pigs.'
Content 4: \gsrc zena keke miyo worä \textbf{ruga mgthksi} ... znsä ttüfr} | \gll zena keke miyo wo\stem{rä} ruga mgthk-si ... znsä t-tüfr. | \gls today NEG desire FSG:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be pig feed-NMLZ ... work REDUP-plenty. | \glt `Today, I do not want to feed pigs ... too much work.' (lit. `I do not desire pig feeding.')

Knowledge Point: In noun-headed compounds, the argument role of the noun with respect to the verb is less determined than in verb-headed compounds. The following argument roles are found: actor (zan kabe `killer'), \isi{patient} (mgthksi ruga `feeding pig' in (\ref{ex539}) above), instrument (bi näbüsi wämne `sago beating stick'), location (yonasi faf `drinking place'), or time (tharisi efoth `harvesting time'). This variability contrasts with verb-headed compounds, where the noun is always a \isi{patient} or \isi{theme}, as in kabe zan `war' (lit. `people hitting'), ruga mgthksi `pig feeding' in (\ref{ex540}) above, or wawa yarisi `yam exchange' (lit. `yam giving'). Note that there is an implied \isi{agent} in most of these examples. It follows that (nominalised) \isi{intransitive} verbs do not participate in verb-headed compounds. For example, there can be a mthizsi kabe `resting person' or a yathizsi kabe `dying person'. But the reverse order is ungrammatical: \textsuperscript{\ast}kabe mthizsi or \textsuperscript{\ast}kabe yathizsi.

(lit. `I do not desire pig feeding.')

Knowledge Point: What is special about the \isi{inclusory} construction in Komnzo is that although both core phrase and \isi{associative} phrase refer to distinct subsets, the \isi{number} marking on each phrase has scope over the total set. Consider example (\ref{ex725}) where the total set encoded in the verb is second/third dual. The two subsets are expressed by the personal names Maureen and Kowi. The core phrase is flagged with a \isi{non-singular} \isi{ergative} (Maureen=é), and the \isi{associative} phrase is flagged with an \isi{dual} \isi{associative} (Kowi=r). The point here is that the scope of the \isi{number} value is always the total set and not the respective subsets.\footnote{Note that literal translations of the inclusory construction are rather clumsy: `Maureen with Kowi beat Sago', whereas idiomatic \ili{English} translations imply that the verb is indexing a singular, as in (\ref{ex725}).}
Content 1: \gsrc Maureené bi ynäbünth Kowir. | \gll maureen=é bi y\stem{näbü}nth kowi=r. | \gls maureen=ERG.NSG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat kowi=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Maureen together with Kowi beats Sago.' (lit. `Maureen with Kowi, they beat Sago.')
Content 2: \gsrc Maureené bi ynäbünth Kowir. | \gll maureen=é bi y\stem{näbü}nth kowi=r. | \gls maureen=ERG.NSG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat kowi=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Maureen together with Kowi beats Sago.' (lit. `Maureen with Kowi, they beat Sago.')

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex725}) shows that a \isi{non-singular} attaches to a personal name. In example (\ref{ex340}), the set encoded in the verb is first \isi{plural}. Note that the core phrase is omitted here, but it could be expressed by the \isi{pronoun} ni (\Fnsg). There are multiple \isi{associative} phrases in the example: nä srakä `with some boy(s)', mafä thzé `with whoever' and Mosesä `with Moses'. Since the total set is bigger than the minimal group, i.e. bigger than two, the \isi{associative} phrase has to be marked as \isi{plural}. Therefore, the personal name Moses is marked for \isi{plural}.
Content 1: \gsrc Maureené bi ynäbünth Kowir. | \gll maureen=é bi y\stem{näbü}nth kowi=r. | \gls maureen=ERG.NSG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat kowi=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Maureen together with Kowi beats Sago.' (lit. `Maureen with Kowi, they beat Sago.')
Content 2: \gsrc nä srakä kwa nyak ... mafä thzé ... Mosesä. | \gll nä srak=ä kwa n\stem{yak} ... maf=ä thzé ... moses=ä. | \gls some boy=ASSOC.Pl FUT FPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/walk ... who=ASSOC.Pl ever ... moses=ASSOC.Pl. | \glt `We will go with some boy(s) ... with whoever ... with Moses.'

Knowledge Point: The abstract structure of the \isi{inclusory} construction is shown in Figure \ref{incluscons}. The circle represents the set, and the line in the middle cuts the total set into two subsets. The arrows on the left point to the referents expressed by each element. Note that there can be more than one \isi{associative} phrase (\ref{ex340}). Examples like (\ref{ex340}) can be further elaborated by adding \isi{associative} phrases, for example Maureenä and Kowiä to mean `with Moses, with Maureen, with Kowi'. These additional \isi{associative} phrases are not represented in Figure \ref{incluscons} because they would receive the same marking as the first \isi{associative} phrase.\footnote{Naturally, this is only possible if there are more than two participants in the total set.} The arrow on the right shows that the \isi{number} value encoded in each element tracks the number of the total set.
Content 1: \gsrc nä srakä kwa nyak ... mafä thzé ... Mosesä. | \gll nä srak=ä kwa n\stem{yak} ... maf=ä thzé ... moses=ä. | \gls some boy=ASSOC.Pl FUT FPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/walk ... who=ASSOC.Pl ever ... moses=ASSOC.Pl. | \glt `We will go with some boy(s) ... with whoever ... with Moses.'
Content 2: \gsrc nä srakä kwa nyak ... mafä thzé ... Mosesä. | \gll nä srak=ä kwa n\stem{yak} ... maf=ä thzé ... moses=ä. | \gls some boy=ASSOC.Pl FUT FPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/walk ... who=ASSOC.Pl ever ... moses=ASSOC.Pl. | \glt `We will go with some boy(s) ... with whoever ... with Moses.'

Knowledge Point: Figure \ref{incluscons} shows that the core phrase always encodes \isi{non-singular} \isi{number}. As we have seen, this holds true for cases where there are only two participants and consequently the two subsets in the core phrase and the \isi{associative} phrase refer to a single individual respectively. The examples below show this for an ergative-marked argument, amayé nanyr `mother with big sister' (\ref{ex605}), an absolutive-marked argument, emothé bnrr `girl with you' (\ref{ex727}), and a dative-marked argument, sraknm nafrr `boy with him' (\ref{ex728}). In contrasting examples without the \isi{inclusory} construction, all of these would receive a \isi{singular} marker of the respective cases. Note that the \isi{non-singular} \isi{absolutive} =é in (\ref{ex727}) is the same as the \isi{non-singular} \isi{ergative} =é in (\ref{ex605}). This syncretism is also found in the personal pronouns, where ni is both first \isi{person} \isi{non-singular} \isi{absolutive} and \isi{ergative} ({\S}\ref{personalpronouns-sec}). The \isi{absolutive} \isi{singular} is always zero-marked, and the \isi{non-singular} formative =é is optional ({\S}\ref{abscase}). In the \isi{inclusory} construction, however, \isi{non-singular} \isi{number} is obligatorily encoded on the core phrase.
Content 1: \gsrc mni ŋagarnth amayé nanyr. | \gll mni ŋa\stem{gar}nth ama=é nane=r. | \gls firewood STDU:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/break mother=ERG.NSG elder.sibling=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Mother together with big sister split firewood.' (lit. `Mother with big sister, they split firewood.')
Content 2: \gsrc kabef emothé emarn bnrr. | \gll kabe=f emoth=é e\stem{mar}n bnrr. | \gls man=ERG.SG girl=ABS.NSG STSG:SBJ>STDU:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/see Second.DU.ASSOC. | \glt `The man sees the girl together with you.' (lit. `The man sees them, the girl with you.')
Content 3: \gsrc ŋafyf sraknm dunzi ärin nafrr. | \gll ŋafe=f srak=nm dunzi ä\stem{ri}n nafrr. | \gls father=ERG.SG boy=DAT.NSG arrow STSG:SBJ>STDU:IO:NONPAST:IPFV/give Third.DU.ASSOC. | \glt `The father gives the arrow to the boy together with him.' (lit. `Father gives them the arrow, the boy with him.')
Content 4: \gsrc kabef emothé emarn bnrr. | \gll kabe=f emoth=é e\stem{mar}n bnrr. | \gls man=ERG.SG girl=ABS.NSG STSG:SBJ>STDU:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/see Second.DU.ASSOC. | \glt `The man sees the girl together with you.' (lit. `The man sees them, the girl with you.')
Content 5: \gsrc mni ŋagarnth amayé nanyr. | \gll mni ŋa\stem{gar}nth ama=é nane=r. | \gls firewood STDU:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/break mother=ERG.NSG elder.sibling=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Mother together with big sister split firewood.' (lit. `Mother with big sister, they split firewood.')

Knowledge Point: If the total set indexed in the verb is two, then it follows that the two phrases can only refer to a single individual, even though the core phrase has to be marked for \isi{non-singular}, as in (\ref{ex725}) and (\ref{ex605}\textendash\ref{ex728}). If the total set indexed in the verb is \isi{plural}, it is unclear whether both subsets are bigger than one or whether one of them is singular and if so, which one. Example (\ref{ex340}) above is unambiguous because the \isi{associative} phrase is expressed by a personal name (Moses=\Assoc.\Pl). If the \isi{associative} phrase it expressed by a noun or \isi{pronoun}, we are left with contextual clues. In example (\ref{ex339}), the speaker talks about marriage customs explaining that his clan will not exchange sisters with those clans with which they share a land boundary. In this example, nafä has to be translated as a \isi{plural} `with them'.

(lit. `Father gives them the arrow, the boy with him.')

Third.ABS opposite STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be ... First opposite. | \glt `We really share a land boundary with them. They are there and we (are) here.' (lit. `we cut the ground with them.')

Knowledge Point: In contrast, in example (\ref{ex343}) nafä refers to a singular `with him'. This example is taken from a text about grief, and the speaker justifies a particular mourning custom by pointing out that he and his family have shared a lifetime with the deceased person.
Content 1: \gsrc ... bänema ni nafä kwamränzrme. ni nafä nzwamnzrm. | \gll ... bäne=ma ni nafä kwa\stem{mrä}nzrme ni nafä nzwa\stem{m}nzrm. | \gls ... Recog=CHAR FNSG ThirdPl.ASSOC FPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/stroll FNSG ThirdPl.ASSOC FPL:SBJ:PST:DUR/dwell. | \glt `... because we walked around with him. We lived with him.'

Knowledge Point: It follows that out of context the \isi{pronoun} nafä can refer to an individual or to a group of people in (\ref{ex339}) and (\ref{ex343}). This is also true for the \isi{pronoun} ni (\Fnsg) in both examples. I pointed out above that the core phrase is always \isi{non-singular}, even if the subset expressed by the core phrase is \isi{singular}. Hence, the \isi{pronoun} ni can refer to an individual or a group of people, and out of context example (\ref{ex339}) can be translated as `I share land with them', `We share land with him' or `We share land with them'. What it cannot mean is `I share land with him'. For this meaning, the verb would have to index a \isi{dual} and the \isi{associative} phrase would have to be marked for \isi{dual} \isi{number}.\footnote{The inclusory construction can be seen as a syntactic equivalent to distributed exponence in the verb morphology ({\S}\ref{verbprelim}).}

Third.ABS opposite STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be ... First opposite. | \glt `We really share a land boundary with them. They are there and we (are) here.' (lit. `we cut the ground with them.')

Knowledge Point: The \isi{inclusory} construction also differs from coordinative constructions ({\S}\ref{clausecoordination}). Example (\ref{ex726}) shows the same state-of-affairs as expressed in (\ref{ex725}) above, but using a conjunctive \isi{coordination}. The main structural differences are that in \isi{coordination}: (i) a \isi{conjunction} like a `and' is required, (ii) the coordinated \isi{noun phrase}s have to precede and follow the \isi{conjunction}, (iii) both \isi{noun phrase}s receive the same \isi{case} marker, (iv) the \isi{case} marker can be \isi{singular}. Note that in (\ref{ex725}) above the \isi{associative} phrase Kowir could occur in all other positions. Nevertheless, the most natural positions are either after the verb or right after Maureené.
Content 1: \gsrc Maureenf a Kowif bi ynäbünth. | \gll Maureen=f a Kowi=f bi y\stem{näbü}nth. | \gls maureen=ERG.SG and kowi=ERG.SG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat. | \glt `Maureen and Kowi beat sago.'
Content 2: \gsrc Maureené bi ynäbünth Kowir. | \gll maureen=é bi y\stem{näbü}nth kowi=r. | \gls maureen=ERG.NSG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat kowi=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Maureen together with Kowi beats Sago.' (lit. `Maureen with Kowi, they beat Sago.')
Content 3: \gsrc Maureené bi ynäbünth Kowir. | \gll maureen=é bi y\stem{näbü}nth kowi=r. | \gls maureen=ERG.NSG sago(ABS) STDU:SBJ>TSG.MASC:OBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/beat kowi=ASSOC.DU. | \glt `Maureen together with Kowi beats Sago.' (lit. `Maureen with Kowi, they beat Sago.')

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, the elements in an \isi{inclusory} construction can be coordinated, as in example (\ref{ex342}), where the two \isi{associative} phrases nä oromanr `with another old man' and nä kabe `with another man' are part of a disjunctive \isi{coordination} connected by o `or'.
Content 1: \gsrc nä oromanr o nä kaber fi bämrn. | \gll nä {oroman=r} o nä kabe=r fi b=ä\stem{m}rn. | \gls INDF old.man=ASSOC.DU or INDF man=ASSOC.DU Third.ABS MED=STDU:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/sit. | \glt `He is sitting there with another old man or another man.' (lit. `...with some old man or with some man they two sit there.')

Knowledge Point: There is no clear semantic difference between \isi{coordination} and the \isi{inclusory} construction, but the difference seems to be pragmatic. While \isi{coordination} places the two elements on the same rank, the \isi{inclusory} construction may be used to highlight the referent expressed in the \isi{associative} phrase. This is supported by the fact that in most corpus examples, the core phrase is omitted, because its reference has been established earlier. Example (\ref{ex342}) above was uttered as the description of a set of picture cards. I reproduce the example in a longer context in (\ref{ex743}). The speaker talks about the protagonist of the story who is drinking with his friends. While describing the picture card, the speaker points out that the protagonist is sitting with another man. He then asks about the topic of their conversation. This other man is expressed in the \isi{associative} phrase. The same state of affairs could be expressed by a coordinative construction (`He and another man are sitting there'). The point is that the \isi{inclusory} construction can be used to introduce a new \isi{participant}, and thus has a pragmatic function. Note that the \isi{associative} phrase occurs in the first position of the clause.
Content 1: \gsrc nä oromanr o nä kaber fi bämrn. | \gll nä {oroman=r} o nä kabe=r fi b=ä\stem{m}rn. | \gls INDF old.man=ASSOC.DU or INDF man=ASSOC.DU Third.ABS MED=STDU:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/sit. | \glt `He is sitting there with another old man or another man.' (lit. `...with some old man or with some man they two sit there.')

DEM all ... EMPH old.woman Dim INDF MED=STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/be ... REDUP-tell-NMLZ STPL:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/tell ... INDF old.man=ASSOC.DU or INDF man=ASSOC.DU Third.ABS MED=STDU:SBJ:NONPAST:IPFV/sit ... platform on.top how but STSG:SBJ>TSG.MASC:IO:NONPAST:IPFV/tell ... TSG.DAT. | \glt `That is the one sitting there. (They are) drunkards ... all of them. There is some woman. They are telling stories. He is sitting there with another old man or another man ... on the platform. But what is he telling him?'
